body: \text{Two point charges } q_1 = 3 \times 10^{-6} \text{ C and } q_2 = -3 \times 10^{-6} \text{ C are placed 10 cm apart in vacuum. Find the electric force acting between them.}
\text{Explain the concept of quantisation of electric charge and give an example illustrating it.}

\text{A charged metallic sphere A is suspended by a nylon thread. Another charged metallic sphere B held by an insulating handle is brought close to A such that the distance between their centres is 10 cm. What will happen if B is brought even closer to A? Justify your answer.}
\text{State Coulomb’s law of electrostatics and express it in vector form.}
\text{Define electric field and electric flux. How is electric flux related to the electric field?}
\text{Derive the expression for the electrostatic potential energy of a system of two point charges in vacuum.}
\text{Calculate the work done in moving a charge of } 5 \; \mu C \text{ between two points on an equipotential surface.}

\text{A parallel plate capacitor is charged by a battery. After some time, the battery is disconnected and a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates. Explain how the capacitance, electric field, and energy of the capacitor are affected.}
\text{Define capacitance and derive an expression for the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor with a dielectric medium.}
\text{Calculate the potential at a point 5 cm away from a point charge of } 4 \times 10^{-7} \text{ C in vacuum.}
\text{State and explain Ohm's law. Describe an experiment to verify Ohm's law.}
\text{Derive the formula for the equivalent resistance when three resistors } R_1, R_2, \text{ and } R_3 \text{ are connected in parallel.}
\text{A wire of resistance } 5 \; \Omega \text{ is stretched to double its original length. Calculate the new resistance of the wire.}
\text{Explain the concept of drift velocity and derive an expression for the current in a conductor in terms of the drift velocity of electrons.}

\text{Determine the current flowing through a conductor of cross-sectional area } 0.2 \; \text{cm}^2 \text{ and free electron density } 10^{29} \text{ electrons/m}^3 \text{ when the drift velocity of electrons is } 10^{-4} \; \text{m/s}.
\text{State and derive the expression for the force on a moving charge in a magnetic field.}
\text{Describe the working principle of a cyclotron and derive an expression for the kinetic energy of a particle accelerated in a cyclotron.}
\text{A charged particle enters a uniform magnetic field and follows a circular path. Explain why this happens and derive an expression for the radius of the circular path.}
\text{State Biot-Savart law and use it to derive an expression for the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop carrying current.}
\text{Calculate the force on a 2 C charge moving at a speed of } 3 \times 10^6 \; \text{m/s perpendicular to a magnetic field of strength } 2 \; \text{T}.
\text{Define magnetic susceptibility and explain how it differs for diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic materials.}
\text{Describe the Earth’s magnetic field and explain the terms magnetic declination and magnetic inclination.}
\text{Explain the concept of magnetic domains and how they contribute to the magnetic properties of ferromagnetic materials.}

\text{A short bar magnet placed in a horizontal plane has its axis aligned along the Earth's magnetic field direction. If the magnetic moment of the bar magnet is } 0.4 \; \text{Am}^2 \text{ and Earth's horizontal field is } 30 \; \mu T \text{, find the magnitude of the torque acting on the magnet.}
\text{Derive an expression for the magnetic field at a point on the axis of a circular current loop.}
\text{State Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction and derive the expression for induced EMF in a coil.}

\text{A circular loop of radius 10 cm is placed in a magnetic field of strength 0.5 T, perpendicular to the plane of the loop. If the magnetic field decreases to 0.2 T in 0.5 s, calculate the induced EMF in the loop.}
\text{Explain Lenz's law and illustrate it with an example.}
\text{Derive an expression for the energy stored in an inductor when current flows through it.}

\text{A coil with 500 turns and cross-sectional area } 2 \; \text{cm}^2 \text{ is placed perpendicular to a magnetic field of strength 0.1 T. If the magnetic field is reversed in direction in 0.1 s, calculate the induced EMF.}
\text{Explain the concept of RMS value of an alternating current and derive the expression for the RMS value of sinusoidal AC.}
\text{Describe the working of a transformer and derive the relation between primary and secondary voltage.}

\text{A series circuit consists of a resistor } (R = 10 \; \Omega), \text{ an inductor } (L = 0.5 \; \text{H}), \text{ and a capacitor } (C = 20 \; \mu F) \text{ connected to a 50 Hz AC source. Calculate the impedance of the circuit.}
\text{Define the power factor in an AC circuit and explain its significance.}
\text{An AC source of } 230 \; \text{V, 50 Hz} \text{ is connected to an inductance of } 0.5 \; \text{H}. \text{ Find the current in the circuit.}
\text{Explain the source of electromagnetic waves and describe their nature.}
\text{State Maxwell’s equations and explain their significance in the context of electromagnetic waves.}
\text{Describe the electromagnetic spectrum and list the uses of different types of electromagnetic waves.}
\text{Calculate the speed of electromagnetic waves in a medium with a permittivity of } 4 \times 10^{-7} \; \text{F/m} \text{ and permeability of } 10^{-7} \; \text{H/m}.
\text{Discuss the concept of displacement current and its role in the continuity of electric current in an AC circuit.}
\text{State Snell’s law of refraction and derive it using Huygens' principle.}
\text{Explain the working principle of a simple microscope and derive an expression for its magnifying power.}
\text{Describe the phenomenon of total internal reflection and derive the critical angle for total internal reflection.}
\text{A convex lens of focal length 20 cm is used to form an image of an object placed 30 cm from the lens. Find the position and nature of the image.}
\text{Explain the construction and working of an astronomical telescope and derive the expression for its magnifying power.}
\text{Explain Young’s double-slit experiment and derive the expression for fringe width.}
\text{Describe the phenomenon of diffraction and explain the conditions under which it occurs.}
\text{Define Brewster’s law and derive an expression for the Brewster angle.}
\text{Explain the formation of Newton's rings and derive the expression for the radius of the nth dark ring.}
\text{A light wave with wavelength 600 nm is incident on a slit of width 0.1 mm. Calculate the angle at which the first diffraction minimum occurs.}
\text{State and explain Einstein's photoelectric equation.}
chapter_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

body: \text{An electron is accelerated through a potential difference of 100 V. Calculate the de Broglie wavelength associated with it.}
chapter_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

body: \text{Explain the phenomenon of photoelectric effect and discuss its experimental observations.}
chapter_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

body: \text{Describe the concept of matter waves and derive the expression for de Broglie wavelength.}
chapter_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

body: \text{Light of wavelength 400 nm ejects photoelectrons from a metal surface with a maximum kinetic energy of 1.2 eV. Find the work function of the metal.}
chapter_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

body: \text{Describe Rutherford’s model of the atom and discuss its limitations.}
\text{State and explain Bohr's postulates for the hydrogen atom.}
\text{Calculate the radius of the first orbit of the hydrogen atom using Bohr's model.}
\text{Explain the concept of energy levels in an atom and derive the expression for the energy of an electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen.}
\text{An electron jumps from the third to the second orbit in a hydrogen atom. Calculate the wavelength of the emitted radiation.}
\text{Define binding energy and binding energy per nucleon. Explain its significance.}
\text{Calculate the binding energy per nucleon of } ^{16}O \text{ if its atomic mass is 15.994915 u.}
\text{State and explain the concept of mass defect and nuclear binding energy.}
\text{Describe the phenomenon of nuclear fission and mention two applications of it.}
\text{Explain the concept of half-life and derive the relation between half-life and decay constant.}
\text{Explain the difference between conductors, semiconductors, and insulators based on band theory.}
chapter_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices, and Simple Circuits

body: \text{Describe the construction and working of a p-n junction diode.}
chapter_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices, and Simple Circuits

body: \text{Explain the concept of doping and its effect on the conductivity of semiconductors.}
chapter_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices, and Simple Circuits

body: \text{Describe the characteristics of a Zener diode and its application in voltage regulation.}
chapter_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices, and Simple Circuits

body: \text{Explain the working of a transistor as an amplifier.}
chapter_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices, and Simple Circuits
